intro: Camellia taheishanensis, commonly known as the Taheishan camellia, is a rare and endemic species native to China. It belongs to the Theaceae family and is characterized by its striking, large, double flowers that range in color from white to deep red. The plant typically grows in subtropical forests, thriving in shaded, moist environments with well-drained soil. Its leaves are dark green, glossy, and elliptical in shape, while its woody structure is robust and adapted to its mountainous habitat. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable subject for botanical research and conservation efforts.
